title: There They Go-Go-Go!
descriptions:
There They Go-Go-Go! (1956) is a brisk, gag-driven animated short that pits a relentlessly optimistic predator against an effortlessly elusive prey across a sunbaked desert. The film opens with a proud pursuer surveying a vast canyon landscape and identifying his target: a swift, almost untouchable speedster who streaks past with a trademark whoosh, leaving only a teasing beep in his wake. The chase is on instantly, and the premise is pure and simple—an endless pursuit in which an elaborate series of traps, gadgets, and schemes are devised, deployed, and then spectacularly backfire.

The pursuer relies on an ever-growing arsenal of catalog-ordered contraptions, each more complicated than the last. The first plan is rudimentary—an ambush along a straightaway where the speedster is certain to pass. But the prey’s effortless acceleration derails it, and the hunter is left inhaling dust. From there, the invention escalates: spring-loaded snares meant to yank the target skyward, a boulder balanced on a hair trigger, and a classic dynamite setup with a fuse that refuses to cooperate. Each device fails with darkly comic precision, always turning the tables so that the pursuer is the one launched, flattened, exploded, or catapulted into open sky before plummeting off a cliff.

Undeterred, the hunter consults his supply crates again. He experiments with rocket-powered footwear to match the speedster’s pace; the boots ignite with promise, then promptly spiral him into a rock wall. A high-tension slingshot is engineered between two granite outcroppings; the trajectory calculations look perfect until wind, gravity, and bad timing combine to send the hunter careening through a painted tunnel entrance that turns out to be only paint for him—but miraculously real passage for the prey. The short delights in visual paradox: physics obeys the laws of comedy, and the prey’s grace is as unflappable as the hunter’s resilience.

Midway through, the landscape becomes as much a character as the duo: needlelike mesas, teetering ledges, looping canyon roads, and treacherous switchbacks. The hunter tries a decoy—an artificial version of the prey, complete with a recorded beep. The real speedster stops, inspects the fake with bemused curiosity, and then zips off as the decoy explodes in the hunter’s face. Another plan involves a giant rubber band stretched across a ravine; instead of catching the runner, it slings the hunter backward into his own supply crate, which detonates in a fireworks display of labels and springs.

There’s a lyrical rhythm to the chase: setups, beats of silence, and then sudden, kinetic payoff. Music cues punctuate each gag, and the prey’s only “dialogue” is a cheerfully taunting honk as he breezes by. The hunter’s persistence is the short’s comic heart; even when flattened to a paper-thin silhouette or reduced to ash, he reconstitutes himself with a sigh, consults a blueprint, and tries again. One elaborate sequence features a towering pile of junk assembled into a mechanical trap—gears, bellows, and a swinging hammer meant to corner the runner into a box. At the decisive moment, the machine collapses with Rube Goldberg inevitability, propelling the hunter upward beneath an anvil that politely hovers just long enough to let him look at the camera before dropping.

In the climax, the hunter commits to a grand plan: a rocket sled designed to outpace even the fleet-footed quarry. He chalks a starting line, dons goggles, and lights the fuse. The sled screams to life, and for a breathless instant he actually gains. But the runner veers, impossibly nimble, and the rocket locks him into a single, unforgiving trajectory that leads straight through a billboard, across a canyon, and into the open door of a freight train car that slams shut and departs in the opposite direction. The hunter’s hand protrudes through a knothole, waving a white flag.

As the desert quiets, the speedster returns for one final glide past the audience, punctuating the silence with a jaunty beep. The short ends where it started—on the open road, with the chase perpetually promised but never complete. There They Go-Go-Go! thrives on repetition and variation, distilling its humor to pure visual invention: no speeches, no plot twists beyond the creative bungling of plans, just the elemental ballet of pursuit and escape, executed with impeccable timing and a sly, self-aware wink.
